G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This action is brought pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and the Court’s inherent and statutory authority to modify prior custody and parenting-time orders upon a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the welfare of the minor children.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This action is brought pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and the Court’s inherent and statutory authority to modify prior custody and parenting-time orders upon a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the welfare of the minor children.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 3.proposition: Venue and jurisdiction are proper in this Court because the prior judgment was issued by this Court, the parties and the Children reside within the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, and this Complaint seeks modification of an existing custody and parenting-time order concerning minor children who reside in this Court’s jurisdiction. See G.L. c. 215, § 3; G.L. c. 208, § 6; G.L. c. 223A, § 3.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 6.proposition: Venue and jurisdiction are proper in this Court because the prior judgment was issued by this Court, the parties and the Children reside within the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, and this Complaint seeks modification of an existing custody and parenting-time order concerning minor children who reside in this Court’s jurisdiction. See G.L. c. 215, § 3; G.L. c. 208, § 6; G.L. c. 223A, § 3.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7 3.proposition: Venue and jurisdiction are proper in this Court because the prior judgment was issued by this Court, the parties and the Children reside within the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, and this Complaint seeks modification of an existing custody and parenting-time order concerning minor children who reside in this Court’s jurisdiction. See G.L. c. 215, § 3; G.L. c. 208, § 6; G.L. c. 223A, § 3.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the paramount consideration in any custody or parenting-time determination, including modification, is the best interests of the child. G.L. c. 208, § 31; G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a).

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 10(a).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the paramount consideration in any custody or parenting-time determination, including modification, is the best interests of the child. G.L. c. 208, § 31; G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a).

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The Court “retains authority to modify custody arrangements when a material change in circumstances has occurred and modification is in the best interests of the child.” See, e.g., *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: Yannas is a removal/relocation case deciding whether a custodial parent may move children out of the Commonwealth, and it articulates the “real advantage” and best-interests framework within the original divorce/custody judgment. It does not discuss post-judgment modification standards, material changes in circumstances, or the court’s retained authority to modify existing custody orders. Therefore, it does not support the specific proposition about modification upon a material change in circumstances, even though it repeatedly refers to the best interests of the child in the initial custody/removal context.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not, if of suitable age to signify his consent, be removed out of this commonwealth without such consent, or, if under that age, without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child . . . and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The Court “retains authority to modify custody arrangements when a material change in circumstances has occurred and modification is in the best interests of the child.” See, e.g., *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: This opinion discusses initial custody determinations and the interaction between the ‘best interests of the child’ standard and the specific factors in G. L. c. 209C, § 10(a); it does not address the court’s continuing authority to *modify* an existing custody order upon a material change in circumstances. The Court explicitly declines to apply or analyze the ‘substantial change in circumstances’ standard under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, treating those modification arguments as waived. Thus, Kali is not authority for the quoted proposition about modification power, even though it cites older cases where custody is ‘subject to revision.’
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”

M.C. v. T.K., 463 Mass. 226, 235\u201323.proposition: A custody or parenting-time judgment may be modified upon a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances, and (2) that modification is necessary in the best interests of the child. See, e.g., *M.C. v. T.K.*, 463 Mass. 226, 235–236 (2012); *Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366, 368–372 (1981) (modification requires material change in circumstances); *Paternity of Cheryl*, 434 Mass. 23, 30–31 (2001).
M.C. v. T.K., 463 Mass. 226, 235\u201323.support_reasoning: The opinion is about initial child support in a shared physical custody, nonmarital context, not about modification of custody or parenting-time judgments. The only reference to ‘materially changed’ circumstances appears in directions on remand regarding reassessing child support based on current incomes, not as a statement of the legal standard for modifying custody or parenting-time orders. The case therefore does not establish or affirm the two-part modification standard described in the proposition.
M.C. v. T.K., 463 Mass. 226, 235\u201323.relevant_excerpt: "On remand, the judge is not required to revisit the issue of the father’s income at the time of trial, but should consider whether the circumstances have materially changed since the date of the judgment before us, and should base any award of child support on the parties’ current incomes."

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368\u.proposition: A custody or parenting-time judgment may be modified upon a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances, and (2) that modification is necessary in the best interests of the child. See, e.g., *M.C. v. T.K.*, 463 Mass. 226, 235–236 (2012); *Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366, 368–372 (1981) (modification requires material change in circumstances); *Paternity of Cheryl*, 434 Mass. 23, 30–31 (2001).
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368\u.support_reasoning: Schuler is a modification case, but it concerns alimony and child support, not custody or parenting time. The opinion states that a party seeking to modify a judgment for alimony or child support must show a material change in circumstances, and then discusses factors including the needs of the children and parents’ financial status, but it does not articulate or apply a specific two-prong ‘material and substantial change plus best interests of the child’ test for custody/parenting-time modifications. Thus it supports the “material change” requirement for financial orders, not the full custody/parenting-time proposition cited.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368\u.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961). Hinds v. Hinds, 329 Mass. 190, 191-192 (1952). … In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances. … The needs of the children, the financial status of the support provider, and the station in life of the respective parties must all be considered.”

Paternity of Cheryl, 434 Mass. 23, 30\u2.proposition: A custody or parenting-time judgment may be modified upon a showing of (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances, and (2) that modification is necessary in the best interests of the child. See, e.g., *M.C. v. T.K.*, 463 Mass. 226, 235–236 (2012); *Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366, 368–372 (1981) (modification requires material change in circumstances); *Paternity of Cheryl*, 434 Mass. 23, 30–31 (2001).
Paternity of Cheryl, 434 Mass. 23, 30\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion in Paternity of Cheryl concerns Rule 60(b) relief from a paternity judgment and the timeliness of attempts to vacate such a judgment based on genetic testing; it does not address modification standards for custody or parenting-time orders. The court’s discussion of ‘best interests of the child’ is in the context of finality of paternity judgments and support obligations, not the two-part material-change-and-best-interests test for modifying custody or parenting time. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the proposition cited.
Paternity of Cheryl, 434 Mass. 23, 30\u2.relevant_excerpt: “There is a compelling public interest in the finality of paternity judgments. … Where a father challenges a paternity judgment, courts have pointed to the special needs of children that must be protected, noting that consideration of what is in a child’s best interests will often weigh more heavily than the genetic link between parent and child. … Like those courts, we have recognized that stability and continuity of support, both emotional and financial, are essential to a child’s welfare.” (434 Mass. at 30–31).

Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that changes in a parent’s work schedule and availability to care for a child can constitute a material change in circumstances justifying modification when those changes materially affect the child’s welfare. See *Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182 (1998) (employment and scheduling issues may warrant modification where they affect care of child); *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404–405 (1981).
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.support_reasoning: The opinion in Rosenberg v. Merida does not discuss changes in a parent’s work schedule, employment, or availability to care for a child as grounds for modification. Its only treatment of custody modification is to note that a material and substantial change is required and to criticize the lack of findings supporting a best-interests determination; the case does not involve or analyze employment or scheduling changes as a material change in circumstances. The proposition attributed to Rosenberg is therefore not supported by this decision, even though Rosenberg does briefly cite Rolde on a different point (parental communication for shared legal custody).
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].’ … The only finding contained in the modification judgment is that ‘the parties are unable to communicate with one another.’ … [T]he judge ‘failed to make specific or detailed findings…’ that awarding sole legal custody… was in the best interests of the child.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404–405 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that changes in a parent’s work schedule and availability to care for a child can constitute a material change in circumstances justifying modification when those changes materially affect the child’s welfare. See *Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182 (1998) (employment and scheduling issues may warrant modification where they affect care of child); *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404–405 (1981).
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: Rolde v. Rolde is a direct-appeal divorce/custody/visitation case, not a post-judgment modification case. The opinion does not discuss ‘material change in circumstances,’ modification standards, or employment/work-schedule changes as a basis to alter an existing judgment. Its custody analysis focuses on best interests, joint vs. sole custody, and parental conflict, not parental work availability or schedule changes. Therefore it does not provide authority for the proposition that changes in a parent’s work schedule can constitute a material change in circumstances justifying modification.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: The husband does argue, however, that it is most often preferred that both parents participate in the child rearing process and in the major decisions that attach thereto. We agree with the precept that “the law sees a value in ‘frequent and continuing contact’ of the child[ren] with both . . . parents.” … However, we agree with the trial judge’s observation that in order for joint custody or shared responsibility to work, both parents must be able mutually “to agree on the basic issues in child rearing and want to cooperate in making decisions for [their] children.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 599 (1.proposition: Decisions concerning primary physical custody and parenting time should promote stability, continuity, and adequate supervision for the child. See *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. at 842–844 (emphasizing stability and continuity); *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 599 (1996) (courts weigh stability, parental fitness, and the child’s daily needs).
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 599 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on requiring explicit findings about domestic violence and its effect on the child when making custody determinations. While it notes factors like the child’s school performance, the parent–child bond, and parental conduct, it does not articulate a general principle that primary physical custody and parenting time should promote stability, continuity, and adequate supervision, nor does it expressly frame the analysis as weighing stability, parental fitness, and the child’s daily needs. Its core holding is about the need to consider and make findings on domestic violence, not about stability/continuity as a general custody standard.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 599 (1.relevant_excerpt: We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below “fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.” … The Probate Court failed to consider the special risks to the child in awarding custody to a father who had committed acts of violence against the mother. … Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.proposition: In evaluating the best interests of the Children, the Court must consider such factors as the children’s age, needs, and welfare; the capacity of each parent to provide personal care and supervision; the children’s routine and stability; and the willingness and ability of each parent to meet the children’s day-to-day needs. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; *Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219, 225–226 (1998); *Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755, 769–770 (1983).
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Adoption of Hugo applies and explains the general ‘best interests of the child’ standard in the context of competing adoption plans and appellate review, but it does not enumerate specific factors such as the children’s age, needs, welfare, parental capacity for personal care and supervision, routine, stability, or day‑to‑day needs. Those particular factors come from other authorities (e.g., G.L. c. 208, § 31 and Custody of a Minor). Hugo focuses on deference to the trial judge and the weighing of expert and lay evidence, not on setting out a specific factor test of the type described in the proposition.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.relevant_excerpt: “Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The ‘best interests of a child’ is a question that presents the trial judge ‘with a classic example of a discretionary decision.’ … We recognize that in this field it is neither possible nor desirable to make decisions with precision, and that ‘much must be left to the trial judge’s experience and judgment.’”

Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 769\u.proposition: In evaluating the best interests of the Children, the Court must consider such factors as the children’s age, needs, and welfare; the capacity of each parent to provide personal care and supervision; the children’s routine and stability; and the willingness and ability of each parent to meet the children’s day-to-day needs. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; *Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219, 225–226 (1998); *Custody of a Minor*, 389 Mass. 755, 769–770 (1983).
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 769\u.support_reasoning: This decision is focused on standards for parental unfitness and the limits on removing a child from a natural parent, not on articulating a multi-factor, best-interests test of the kind stated in the proposition. While it discusses the relationship between parental fitness and the child’s welfare, it does not set out or apply specific factors such as age, routine, day‑to‑day needs, or comparative abilities of each custodian in the way G.L. c. 208, § 31 and later cases do. Thus, it does not provide direct authority for the detailed best-interests factors claimed in the proposition.
Custody of a Minor, 389 Mass. 755, 769\u.relevant_excerpt: “‘[T]he critical question is whether the natural parents are currently fit to further the welfare and best interests of the child.’ … ‘State intervention in the parent-child relationship is justified only when parents appear unable to provide for their children’s care and protection.’ … Evidence that is at least ‘clear and convincing’ is constitutionally required for a finding of parental unfitness… The removal of a child from the custody of his or her parents may be ordered only upon a demonstration by specific and detailed findings that the welfare of the child makes removal necessary.”
